title: How to Live Urgently

steps.headline: Break out of doldrums.
steps.description: Plan beyond "tomorrow" and the "day-after-tomorrow"... but the most urgent day where you live is always today but it points to your tomorrow. Your life today has to be on or the path -- and it is necessary to work on success (that  means progress), including getting the best advice if you need it, or school counseling, the help of others to reach the thrill of victory.

steps.headline: Bring "urgent" -- exciting, important or thrilling ideas and events to the forefront of your life view -- for example:
steps.description: Plan for education, career, spiritual matters, health -- but make time for your reading, meditation on your area of studies -- even relaxation, that may all be important to you. So you are getting lined-up to make it happen each day as you follow the path that you chose...

steps.headline: Start by scheduling your priority items: not prioritizing your schedule.
Change your schedule to your priorities -- not the other way around.
steps.description: Stop Making Excuses: Get your big plan and your nuggets as objectives (most important goals) and your best idea into first place for working in and around your daily life and schedule. Your schedule may be necessary, but your goals should not be sliding back or off the path because of routine, daily troubles.

steps.headline: Effectively Track and Accomplish Your Goals, ie: how you achieve goals should be "on purpose."
steps.description: Think about your family -- about handling life's short term and long term goals with them -- and with your friends and colleagues -- whatever applies. Some people along the way are helpful and some are less worthy, but treat them well.

steps.headline: Make time to do things that matter early each day; so that first things come first, before whatever else you can do that doesn't matter as much.
steps.description: Pick your 3 or 4 Things to Do (ToDo's or TD's) early. Set priorities of which to do first, second, third,... early each day before spending time on tasks that matter so much less.

steps.headline: Pay yourself first.
steps.description: It's an emergency. Maybe you want to write, read, work out, pray or plan at the break of dawn. Do it. Making your allotted 16 waking hours work for you each day. This way every day begins and stays positively aligned, if you start early toward your future and living the minutes, moment by moment.

steps.headline: Do an exciting, fun inventory to organize your goals and plans.
steps.description: Make a two column list of your important or favorite ideas and skills and your less favorite ideas and memories, people and events -- and you’ll see how and why you became the person who reached where you are today.

steps.headline: Look ahead (planning not just hoping) about five years up the road: "see what you want" and then start to plan it out -- so focus energies now and focus every time you have a day of planning time like today on progress...
Write a Mission Statement: Determine your life’s meaning to provide a clue of where you must spend your time on activities for that outcome, on a foundation -- building on it.
steps.description: Maintain relationships today as part of life’s purpose and which help in achieving your life’s urgent mission.

steps.headline: Align your purpose with a dream like a “career goal” and include keeping yourself out of excessive debt but so you can have the resources for travel if needed and for your mission adventures, and to be able to send your children to
Redirect your efforts from merely paying your bills which may mean little time for your ultimate, urgent goals – but you wish you were living your real purposes.
steps.description: Make that urgent to straighten it out.

steps.headline: Get excited to jump out of bed each morning -- and remember or determine each day what you will achieve?
steps.description: There are never enough hours in a day for everything.

steps.headline: Find enough time in each day to do what truly matters...
Find what you can let go.
steps.description:
Let it go. Check the possible consequences of not doing some goal -- of it not happening – but how much do those consequences matter to you. Look at the pay-off, rewards, and even if they sound impressive – but as an accomplishment they have little real meaning to you -- do you need that? You won't be satisfied with doing what doesn't matter to you. You don't care about it; regardless of how important it is to siblings parents, and greater family and others, or how impressive it may be to yourself -- or how important it was before, it may be time to: 
Can you let go of getting a new/newer car every 2 years? Can you let go of signing up for 30 years of payments for a more expensive house?

steps.headline: Lock in your evenings, your dating life and/or family and evening meals as much as anything else in life.
steps.description: It’s a commitment to your life -- the future.

steps.headline: Treat your important mission as an emergency.
Do not slide your future to the back.
steps.description: It must not backslide. Your routine can pause and stop; let those routine things fall, slide down, and make time to rise and climb into your future that matters.

steps.headline: Clear unnecessary items off your schedule.
steps.description: Time spent on what doesn’t matter is time you lose forever – and that is a tragedy for your hope in life, and your future. It is not someone's future; it's your urgent life. Walk it out, hurry to do what matters.

text:
Break out of doldrums. Plan beyond "tomorrow" and the "day-after-tomorrow"... but the most urgent day where you live is always today but it points to your tomorrow. Your life today has to be on or the path -- and it is necessary to work on success (that  means progress), including getting the best advice if you need it, or school counseling, the help of others to reach the thrill of victory. Bring "urgent" -- exciting, important or thrilling ideas and events to the forefront of your life view -- for example: Plan for education, career, spiritual matters, health -- but make time for your reading, meditation on your area of studies -- even relaxation, that may all be important to you. So you are getting lined-up to make it happen each day as you follow the path that you chose... Start by scheduling your priority items: not prioritizing your schedule.  Change your schedule to your priorities -- not the other way around. Stop Making Excuses: Get your big plan and your nuggets as objectives (most important goals) and your best idea into first place for working in and around your daily life and schedule. Your schedule may be necessary, but your goals should not be sliding back or off the path because of routine, daily troubles. Effectively Track and Accomplish Your Goals, ie: how you achieve goals should be "on purpose." Think about your family -- about handling life's short term and long term goals with them -- and with your friends and colleagues -- whatever applies. Some people along the way are helpful and some are less worthy, but treat them well. Make time to do things that matter early each day; so that first things come first, before whatever else you can do that doesn't matter as much. Pick your 3 or 4 Things to Do (ToDo's or TD's) early. Set priorities of which to do first, second, third,... early each day before spending time on tasks that matter so much less. Pay yourself first. It's an emergency. Maybe you want to write, read, work out, pray or plan at the break of dawn. Do it. Making your allotted 16 waking hours work for you each day. This way every day begins and stays positively aligned, if you start early toward your future and living the minutes, moment by moment. Do an exciting, fun inventory to organize your goals and plans. Make a two column list of your important or favorite ideas and skills and your less favorite ideas and memories, people and events -- and you’ll see how and why you became the person who reached where you are today. Look ahead (planning not just hoping) about five years up the road: "see what you want" and then start to plan it out -- so focus energies now and focus every time you have a day of planning time like today on progress...  Write a Mission Statement: Determine your life’s meaning to provide a clue of where you must spend your time on activities for that outcome, on a foundation -- building on it. Maintain relationships today as part of life’s purpose and which help in achieving your life’s urgent mission. Align your purpose with a dream like a “career goal” and include keeping yourself out of excessive debt but so you can have the resources for travel if needed and for your mission adventures, and to be able to send your children to  Redirect your efforts from merely paying your bills which may mean little time for your ultimate, urgent goals – but you wish you were living your real purposes. Make that urgent to straighten it out. Get excited to jump out of bed each morning -- and remember or determine each day what you will achieve? There are never enough hours in a day for everything. Find enough time in each day to do what truly matters...  Find what you can let go. Let it go. Check the possible consequences of not doing some goal -- of it not happening – but how much do those consequences matter to you. Look at the pay-off, rewards, and even if they sound impressive – but as an accomplishment they have little real meaning to you -- do you need that? You won't be satisfied with doing what doesn't matter to you. You don't care about it; regardless of how important it is to siblings parents, and greater family and others, or how impressive it may be to yourself -- or how important it was before, it may be time to: 
Can you let go of getting a new/newer car every 2 years? Can you let go of signing up for 30 years of payments for a more expensive house? Lock in your evenings, your dating life and/or family and evening meals as much as anything else in life. It’s a commitment to your life -- the future. Treat your important mission as an emergency. First things are critical: urgent. Do not slide your future to the back. It must not backslide. Your routine can pause and stop; let those routine things fall, slide down, and make time to rise and climb into your future that matters. Clear unnecessary items off your schedule. Time spent on what doesn’t matter is time you lose forever – and that is a tragedy for your hope in life, and your future. It is not someone's future; it's your urgent life. Walk it out, hurry to do what matters.
